metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof The COVID-19 Pandemic and Acute Aortic Dissections in New York: A Matter of Public Health The COVID-19 Pandemic and Acute Aortic Dissections in New York: A Matter of Public Health

abstract.text: Word of Caution: # of surgical repair for Type A aortic dissection, a life-threatening emergency, in NYC plummeted after COVID19 pandemic.

body_text.text: As of April 15, 2020, the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in New York City (NYC) was >110,000, making it the global epicenter of the pandemic. (1) This rapid surge in the number of cases imposed a major burden on all hospitals in NYC, as well as a significant stress in Emergency Departments (ED). In addition, public health messages promoting social distancing and news reports focused on the death toll associated with COVID-19 have created a sense of generalized anxiety in society. Changes in the observed incidence of acute cardiovascular conditions have been anecdotally reported, including the occurrence of STelevation myocardial infarctions 2 . Incidentally, the number of at-home deaths in NYC have reached an 8-to 10-fold increase compared to the same time period in 2019, raising concerns about the impact of the pandemic on non-COVID related health conditions. Acute type A aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition for which the only effective treatment requires a surgical intervention and the portal to initial diagnosis is invariably the ED.

In the absence of emergent surgical intervention, thirty-day mortality after an acute type A aortic dissection ranges from 50% to 60% (2). The COVID-19 crisis has created additional challenges in ED, such as more layers of screening through pre-ED triage and registration, reduced individual patient attention, rationing of timely CT scanning, and confusing the atypical symptoms of type A aortic dissection with common COVID-19 presentations.

To investigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the incidence of acute type A aortic dissections, we compiled data from all hospitals/health systems providing cardiac surgery in NYC (N=11). This allowed capturing all cases of surgical repair of acute type A aortic dissections from January 1, 2018 to April 15, 2020. No change in the management of acute type A aortic dissections was reported by any of the centers. All patients with acute type A aortic dissection in NYC underwent emergent open repair. Univariable linear regression was used to calculate the estimated decrease in monthly procedural volumes between before-COVID and after-COVID. The cutoff between before and after was March 1, 2020, corresponding to the first reported case in NYC. Because this study includes no PHI, Columbia University's institutional review board advised that this study is exempt from IRB submission.

There was a significant and precipitous drop in the monthly surgical case volume of acute type A aortic dissection from 12.8±4.6 cases/month before-COVID to 3.0 ±1.0 cases/month after-COVID, representing a 76.5% decrease in volume (Figure 1) . This decline was statistically

BIBREF1.title: The International Registry of Acute Aortic Dissection (IRAD): new insights into an old disease

BIBREF2.title: Chronobiological patterns of acute aortic dissection

FIGREF0.text: significant by regression analysis (9.8;95%CI:2.95,16.67;p=0.007). Low volumes in 2 consecutive months (March and April, 2020) further confirms the unusual nature of the observation. Given the known seasonal effect with a higher incidence of dissections during the winter months (3), analysis of the volumes in the 4 months (January to April) of the last 3 years further confirmed the unusually low volumes after-COVID. While no causal relationship can be firmly established between the drop in type A aortic dissections, the COVID-19 outbreak in NYC and the increase in at-home deaths since the last week of March, 2020, this gives pause for thought. A number of hypotheses may explain this observation including patient fear of contracting COVID-19 if presenting to the ED, overstretched first responders causing undue delays, overburdened EDs causing delayed or missed diagnoses. Importantly, this raises important public health concerns about the unintended consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is critical, as we adjust to the pandemic, to balance the public health imperative of social distancing with the individual need to consult in the presence of sudden severe symptoms. Furthermore, additional resources ranging from telemedicine to increased first responders should be greatly increased. This serves as a word of Figure Legend

FIGREF1.text: Trend of Type A Repair Volume. (A) Variation in monthly volumes of surgically treated acute type A aortic dissections (blue line, left vertical axis) and COVID-19 cases (red bar, right vertical axis) in New York City from January 1, 2018 to April 15, 2020. (B) Decrease in average monthly volumes before-and after-COVID19 (p<0.05).
